messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 44 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Robust testing of low-dimensional functions

Paper Abstract: Abstract A natural problem in high-dimensional inference is to decide if a classifier f:ℝn→{−1,1}:𝑓→superscriptℝ𝑛11f:\mathbb{R}^{n}\rightarrow\{-1,1\} depends on a small number of linear directions of its input data. Call a function g:ℝn→{−1,1}:𝑔→superscriptℝ𝑛11g:\mathbb{R}^{n}\rightarrow\{-1,1\}, a linear k𝑘k-junta if it is completely determined by some k𝑘k-dimensional subspace of the input space. A recent work of the authors showed that linear k𝑘k-juntas are testable. Thus there exists an algorithm to distinguish between: 1. f:ℝn→{−1,1}:𝑓→superscriptℝ𝑛11f:\mathbb{R}^{n}\rightarrow\{-1,1\} which is a linear k𝑘k-junta with surface area s𝑠s, 2. f𝑓f is ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-far from any linear k𝑘k-junta with surface area (1+ϵ)​s1italic-ϵ𝑠(1+\epsilon)s, where the query complexity of the algorithm is independent of the ambient dimension n𝑛n. Following the surge of interest in noise-tolerant property testing, in this paper we prove a noise-tolerant (or robust) version of this result. Namely, we give an algorithm which given any c>0𝑐0c>0, ϵ>0italic-ϵ0\epsilon>0, distinguishes between 1. f:ℝn→{−1,1}:𝑓→superscriptℝ𝑛11f:\mathbb{R}^{n}\rightarrow\{-1,1\} has correlation at least c𝑐c with some linear k𝑘k-junta with surface area s𝑠s. 2. f𝑓f has correlation at most c−ϵ𝑐italic-ϵc-\epsilon with any linear k𝑘k-junta with surface area at most s𝑠s. The query complexity of our tester is k𝗉𝗈𝗅𝗒​(s/ϵ)superscript𝑘𝗉𝗈𝗅𝗒𝑠italic-ϵk^{\mathsf{poly}(s/\epsilon)}. Using our techniques, we also obtain a fully noise tolerant tester with the same query complexity for any class 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} of linear k𝑘k-juntas with surface area bounded by s𝑠s. As a consequence, we obtain a fully noise tolerant tester with query complexity kO​(𝗉𝗈𝗅𝗒​(log⁡k/ϵ))superscript𝑘𝑂𝗉𝗈𝗅𝗒𝑘italic-ϵk^{O(\mathsf{poly}(\log k/\epsilon))} for the class of intersection of k𝑘k-halfspaces (for constant k𝑘k) over the Gaussian space. Our query complexity is independent of the ambient dimension n𝑛n. Previously, no non-trivial noise tolerant testers were known even for a single halfspace.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 44 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 44"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Do deep nets really need to be deep?",
        "Active property testing.",
        "Free bits, PCPs, and nonapproximability–towards tight results.",
        "Matrix analysis, volume 169.",
        "Improved bounds for testing juntas.",
        "Testing juntas nearly optimally.",
        "Tolerant junta testing and the connection to submodular optimization and function isomorphism.",
        "Relevant examples and relevant features: Thoughts from computational learning theory.",
        "A polynomial time algorithm for learning noisy linear threshold functions.",
        "Selection of relevant features and examples in machine learning.",
        "Model compression.",
        "Junto-symmetric functions, hypergraph isomorphism and crunching.",
        "Distribution free junta testing.",
        "Sample-Based High-Dimensional Convexity Testing.",
        "Settling the query complexity of non-adaptive junta testing.",
        "Complexity theoretic limitations on learning halfspaces.",
        "Is your function low dimensional?",
        "Junta correlation is testable.",
        "Testing for concise representations.",
        "Distribution-independent PAC learning of halfspaces with Massart noise.",
        "Learning geometric concepts with nasty noise.",
        "Testing juntas.",
        "Hardness of learning halfspaces with noise.",
        "Distribution-Free Property Testing.",
        "An invariance principle for polytopes.",
        "Toward Efficient Agnostic Learning.",
        "Learning geometric concepts via Gaussian surface area.",
        "Testing surface area.",
        "Semigroup proofs of the isoperimetric inequality in Euclidean and Gauss space.",
        "The geometry of markov diffusion generators.",
        "Risk bounds for statistical learning.",
        "Testing halfspaces.",
        "Testing ±plus-or-minus\\pm1-weight halfspace.",
        "On the reciprocal of the general algebraic matrix.",
        "Testing surface area with arbitrary accuracy.",
        "Analysis of Boolean functions.",
        "Tolerant property testing and distance approximation.",
        "Testing Basic Boolean Formulae.",
        "A generalized inverse for matrices.",
        "Probabilistic methods in the geometry of Banach spaces.",
        "Exponentially improved algorithms and lower bounds for testing signed majorities.",
        "Sampling from large matrices: An approach through geometric functional analysis.",
        "Adaptivity helps for testing juntas.",
        "Learning convex concepts from gaussian distributions with PCA."
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 44 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Robust testing of low-dimensional functions, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
